Anander lets Anetor wot,</br>His Love, his Lady, and his Lot.

A civill Youth, whose life was led in Court,</br>—In Court, the place of all Civilitie;—</br>Who lov'd no riot, tho delighted sport,</br>Such sport as with such place might well agree</br>To give him credite, by a true report:</br>The only glory of his time was hee:</br>For (mote I sweare,) the gentry of his kind,</br>Was fairely match'd with gentlenes of mind.

His personage, a thing for Gods to tell,</br>Whose wits can reach, beyond the reach of Muse;</br>Divine proportion in his limmes did dwell,</br>Eye-wonder'd feature did his visage use:</br>He was (as may the wiser tell,)</br>For Ladies choice, (if Ladies list to chuse:)</br>If not, what help?  the weaker his successe,</br>Though his perfections be nothing lesse.

His birth was great, his bloud the nobler then,</br>His thoughts (no doubt) the worthier by his bloud;</br>And his desires, though somewhat like to men,</br>Yet as his thoughts (I guesse) were faire and good:</br>And for his loves, none knew them but him sen,</br>And that faire she, on whom their fortune stood:</br>Yet did he often plaine of ill succeed;</br>The hoter love, somtime the colder speed.

And in his passions, (for I must needs breake</br>Into some speech of him, and his mis-lot;)</br>He unto me, as whom he lov'd, did speake</br>The cleare discov'rie of his eager plot</br>In gracefull termes, and yet the best too weake,</br>To tell his thoughts sufficiently (God wot:)</br>That I should often stand and weepe to see,</br>His griefes more copious then his language bee.

First did he lay his fine unswarfed hand</br>Upon my shoulder, close unto my necke;</br>And then for twentie minutes did he stand,</br>As one that spar'd to speake, in feare of checke:</br>Then sighs, then speakes, but speakes words three times scand,</br>As if he durst not trust his tongues defect:</br>Lest in his woes, his woes might seeme to bite</br>Th' unfriendly dealings of his hearts delight.

Shepheard (quoth he) and giv's me one faint smile,</br>That signifi'de a long sustained wrong;</br>Suffer a Courtier to record a stile,</br>More zealous then the Thracian widow's song:</br>When he in his immortall Musicks guile</br>Besought the freedome of his wife so long:</br>With pitty marke the treatize of my ruth;</br>The like hereafter may befall thy youth.

Meanewhile, the childhood of thy younger wit,</br>That never did more then thy flocks regard,</br>Shall have a stronger cause to wonder it,</br>Then those that like my haples selfe hath car'd:</br>While I, ne vowes, ne circumstance omit</br>Of those mishaps, wherein I have bene snar'd:</br>Under the leave (sweet boy) of thy forbearing;</br>An elders griefe profits a youngers hearing.

Woo'd thou had'st had in Court but halfe that skill,</br>As here thou hast with thy obezant sheepe;</br>T' have seene the strictnes of a Ladies will,</br>And how unmov'd she doth hir favor keepe;</br>T' have knowne the hardship of a Lover's ill,</br>And what a wretchednes it is to weepe:</br>And I had kept thy pastures as mine owne;</br>No life too base where better is unknowne.

Then hadst thou seene faire Muridellaes eyes,</br>The dangerous planets of my ripening youth;</br>Thou shoud'st have knowne how beautifull, how wise</br>My Lady was:  Perhaps unto thy ruth</br>Thou shouldst ha' knowne, more then thou canst devise</br>Of that deare Girle, and yet no more then truth:</br>For he that mounts the high'st degree of hie,</br>In praising of her Beautie, cannot lie.

But he that sai's the mercy of hir minde</br>Is like the grace of hir admired blee;</br>He might doe well to bridle in that winde,</br>Untill his fortune were to speake with me:</br>Lesse it be one, to whom sh' ha's beene more kinde,</br>Then to my true affection she cou'd be:</br>And then I thanke him to commend hir hart,</br>For the best Love deserves the best report.

Yet shalt thou thinke, that that deare truth I beare</br>To that faire Sight that first subdude mine eie,</br>Shall say the best, although she be not here,</br>To see how woe, how discontent am I:</br>That when henceforth it comes unto hir eare,</br>That I speake wonders of hir Curtesie;</br>She may recall me with a gracious minde,</br>For praising of hir when she was unkinde.

And if it ever be thy hap to view</br>Her on this greene, where thou inhabitest,</br>First, for my sake, salute her to the shoo,</br>And tell hir with so solemne a protest,</br>That her poore servant, and hir only true,</br>Doth live that life, that she with hate disblest:</br>How, where, and in what sorrow, let her know:</br>She loves to heare, though not to helpe my woe.

Sha't know her by that bright and curious brow,</br>Where Love in his eternall triumph sits</br>Chastising with the warfarre of his bow</br>The rumour of desires, the force of wits;</br>And by her eyes, and other glories moe,</br>That first in me wrought these rebellious fits:</br>But (to be short) if thou a thousand see,</br>Looke which is fairest, and be sure that's shee.

Hir hand (if thou hir hand canst naked see</br>From those blest muffes that guard their blisfull whitenes,)</br>Is like that gripe that Alpheus maz'd to see,</br>Place Arethusa in perpetuall brightnes,</br>And by her foote these plaines shall blessed bee,</br>Unles the ground relent not at her lightnes:</br>Hir substance is so girt in slender finenes,</br>That nothing's heavy, but hir owne unkindenes.

But that thou mayst believe she is a creature</br>As hardly else thou mout'st conceive the same,</br>I tell thee shall:  when that Creatres nature</br>Once set a Princely webbe into her frame,</br>And was about to loome her sacred feature,</br>T'is sed, that in the while Minerva came,</br>Who by enquirie faine would understand,</br>What blessed body now she had in hand.

Nature, for then, no otherwise inclinde</br>In thought but to obezant curtesie,</br>Freely acquaints the goddes of hir minde</br>And humbly craves hir gracious remedie,</br>In such defects, as may hir wisedome finde</br>In this new portion of hir huswifery;</br>Or if at least there might no fault bee had,</br>Yet, that she would some more perfection adde.

For truth she said, that whensoe're she might</br>Once bring to good this Idoll that she wrought,</br>She would present it to the gracious sight</br>Of hir owne selfe, (for so she had bethought);</br>And since hir comming now fell out so right,</br>The larger was her hope, that she had brought</br>Some ornamentall grace, whose large infusing</br>Might make it fit the gift, and worth the chusing.

Then Pallas tooke into her owne embrace</br>This curious Plot that Nature was about,</br>Having no meanes to worke into hir face</br>This bloud that glorifies hir shape without,</br>Nor could of Venus borrow any grace,</br>Cause they alate had sharpely fallen out,</br>Therefore bids Nature for some beautie goe:</br>High hearts disdaine the kindenes of the foe.

Meanewhile from th' issue of that sacred vaine,</br>That her whole selfe with wits abundance fills,</br>She freely powres into this Infants braine,</br>By hony drops; and plentifull distills</br>That puissant conceit that now doth raigne</br>Over herselfe, her Love, her Lovers ills:</br>Yet by this gift hir selfe no lesse cou'd have;</br>She gave hir selfe what to her owne she gave.

Two silver cuppes then drew she from her brest,</br>The one of Spirit and hauty influence,</br>The other fild with maydenly Protest</br>Of Chastities divinest continence;</br>Some drops whereof she in this hart imprest,</br>Therein to double Natures excellence:</br>But chiefely in these heav'nly honours three,</br>Of Wisedome, Puissance, and Chastitie.

Yet hast thou leave to thinke, and so doe I,</br>(Unlesse my thoughts should sinne in thinking so,)</br>That loves wise daughter did not meane hereby</br>That both these gifts should be alike in show:</br>For if her Chastnes live perpetually,</br>As does hir spirit, Ananders cake were dow;</br>Though never gift descended from above</br>Of greater honesty then honest love.

Then neither is her labour vainely spent,</br>Nor yet her gifts in idlenes defray'd,</br>If Muridella with true love content</br>Anander, in encreasing Loves decay'd:</br>For why doth civill curtesie consent</br>The marri'd wife to goe above the mayde?</br>Because the Life by Love is doubly grac'de,</br>And to be wed is more then to be chaste.

This, while the busie dame in eager post,</br>Comes home to see how faire hir worke went on,</br>And from an Ivory boxe of wonders cost,</br>That friendly Venus had bestowed upon</br>Her, for her Infant sake, began to cast,</br>With greater art then was in Belus son,</br>That red and white:  thus, in hir beauties making,</br>Nature and heav'ns themselves were al pertaking.

And this is it that holdes in Love and Muse</br>The two blacke circles of my conquer'd sight,</br>What wondrous cunning Nature seem'd to use</br>In placing of this mingled faire so right,</br>And what a skill she shewed when she did chuse</br>So red a crimson, and so white a white:</br>O heav'ns (sed I) what gifts were Beauties Peeres,</br>If it might never beene yclad in yeares?

Thus, or as like to thus as I can say,</br>The youth, concluding his teare-liquored vaine,</br>Leaves my unletter'd thoughts to beare away</br>Both what he said and what he wood ha saine;</br>And though I want his griefe, yet sure I may</br>Well ground upon his passionate complaine,</br>His Love was faire, and blest in every lim,</br>With no default, but that she lov'd not him.

My youngling wit amuzed at the hearing</br>Of that her dayes had no conversement in,</br>Like a new-fielded souldier, wanting chearing,</br>Stands all astoni'd, two conceits betwin;</br>Whether I mote with small or no forbearing,</br>Burden some disobedience upon him,</br>Or shou'd in verdict of dispraises tuch</br>Her whom himselfe durst [not] dispraise too much.

If you (quoth I) have never yet misdone,</br>To their faire Lady more then I can deeme</br>In these your words; By heav'n, and by this Sunne,</br>Your Service should deserve a more esteeme.</br>But if (alas) your selfe y' have over-run</br>In things to her that mote ungratefull seeme,</br>Grudge not a sharpe rewardance of the same;</br>Men must doe well that wou'd enjoy good name.

With this, about to aske him somwhat more,</br>With hasty answer, and a hearty oth,</br>He clips my speech; and said, and vow'd, and swore,</br>No spot of guilt in his attaintles troth;</br>But as t'is now, so ever heretofore:</br>Quoth I, the better, for I would be loth;</br>Though now I aske you, as t'is fit he shu'd</br>Well know your ill, that must procure your good.

Yet did my soule within it selfe y-doubt</br>No undeservings in his noble heart,</br>Though I (for reasons sake,) mote go about</br>To shew him that I fear'd some undesart:</br>He mought ha thought me, else, some soothing lout,</br>Ylearn'd in neither judgement, nor good part,</br>To discommend hir thoughts, and mourne his fall,</br>Without examining the cause of all.

Yet speake no further of thy chaunce, said I,</br>A single cause wou'd have a single telling,</br>But griefes discourse, hopes mortall enemy,</br>Tat's his prevailing in his oft revealing:</br>O give me leave, saith he, to balme mine eie,</br>And let those teares that hurt it give it healing!</br>For since hir loves are not disposde to granting,</br>Poore helpes are welcome, when the best are wanting.

These teares shall witnes, (when he wept indeed,)</br>How neere unto my soule hir envy crept;</br>How much my hart doth hir owne substance bleed,</br>In fresh remembrance of what vowes I kept,</br>And in what hate that Lady did exceed,</br>That threw me downe to this (and still he wept);</br>O thing for ever to be unforgot,</br>Untill she loves me, as she loves me not.

My flocks this while, that saw their maisters eie</br>Perus'd in things untutching their estate,</br>Ywended to a neighbors sev'ral nie,</br>That for faire feed was mounded in alate:</br>Where lest they shou'd too much offendingly</br>Ore-ramp the grasse, and get the owners hate,</br>I crav'd his name, and leave away to go;</br>No shame to part, when need compelles thereto.

My name tho now it may a causer be</br>Of too long memory of a man forlorne;</br>Is called Anander of the Court (quoth he),</br>Though never Country-man abid more scorne:</br>Yet keep it as thy heardlam close to thee,</br>That no day heare it but that blessed morne</br>Wherein that angell of my good and ill</br>Salutes thy flocks, and thee, upon this hill.

Then tell hir, when she gives thee hir good morrow,</br>That thou alate didst see Anander here;</br>And then speake teares of my unfained sorrow,</br>Or speake unfained sorrow of my teares:</br>And when she doth some light occasion borrow</br>Of other reasons to employ hir eares,</br>Seeme thou as if thou didst not understand hir,</br>And mixe thy speeches with distrest Anander.

If she dispraise or praise thy wanton flocke,</br>Tell thou hir that Anander did so too;</br>If brode the field she for some mate doth looke,</br>Anander, (tell hir,) thus did looke for you;</br>And let remembrance worke some better lucke,</br>For sure I am more harme it cannot do;</br>And sometimes absence do's ingender Passion,</br>By giving leasure to consideration.

So hie thee to thy sheep (good Shepheard boy:)</br>But stay, (O) first enrich me with thy name;</br>Anetor of the Field, (Sir), did I say,</br>Though (understand yee) I am not the same</br>That in amendall of the woolves annoy</br>That mighty voyage unto Peleus, came:</br>Anetor he, and I Anetor am;</br>But he serv'd Peleus, I as good a man.

Discourses ended:  t'was now time a day</br>For him to ride, and for myselfe to wander;</br>Such causes call us both, we cannot stay;</br>His dear's at Court, and my deere flockes be yonder:</br>And all our part no more but this to say,</br>Farewell Anetor, and farewell Anander:</br>Save that in our farewelles, this wish we move,</br>Me to recall my Flocks, and he his Love.</br>
